data.text: Do Carbon HandleBars Reduce Vibration on the Bicycle

Would carbon handlebars provide any additional benefit to reducing vibration if I already have a Redshift stem? I‚Äôm thinking it might dampen the amplitude a bit but not sure if it‚Äôs worth the cost. Thanks in advance!
worth the cost
data.author: Larry Narachi

data.text: What tire pressure do you run on what sized tire?
data.author: Kevin Lee

data.text: lol I squeezed 700x50mm tires onto my warbird. 30 psi. I deal with a touch of carpal tunnel, but I think I‚Äôm mostly looking for an excuse to get a set of carbon bars. üôÉ
data.author: Chris Hong

data.text: You ain't noticing anything with 50mm tires at 30psi.
data.author: Mikey Mutz

data.text: try 26 psi.
data.author: Dave Evetts

data.text: Yes and that is why all my bikes have a carbon bar.
data.author: John Shoemaker

data.text: Maybe. Depends on the bar. I actually swapped from original carbon bar to Al Ritchey Venturemax on my Giant revolt and find it more comfortable. The added flare possibly helps with flex and not all Al is equal. On the other hand I swapped a cheap Al bar to carbon on my road bike with equally positive results. Good bar tape and the right tyre pressure are obviously important too.
data.author: John Knapp

data.text: I have aluminum salsa cowbells. I really like the flair and the drops. Very comfortable for 90% of the ride
data.author: Chris Hong

data.text: try changing the bar tape before changing the bars as branded carbon bars can be expensive. That said, I‚Äôve had success with off brand bars which I think some criticize out of hand without ever trying them.
data.author: Raphael K Koikoi

data.text: I‚Äôve had carbon bars that were attached to carbon everything else , can‚Äôt say that they‚Äôre anymore comfortable than good old alloy . Think relaxing your grip and staying loose on the bike makes the most difference
data.author: David Riley

data.text: How often do you crash?
data.author: Andrew Yee

data.text: errr‚Ä¶a fair amount. Are carbon bars really that much more fragile than frames?
data.author: Chris Hong

data.text: yeah, because of the leverage and small stress area at the stem and lever clamp. And so hard to inspect under tape. Aluminum will bend, won't like bending back, but will show you it's weakened. Carbon not so much. A second wrap of bar tape will make more of a difference for comfort than material.
data.author: Andrew Yee

data.text: that makes a lot of sense.
data.author: Chris Hong

data.text: they're not in fashion, but even padded gloves make a difference!
data.author: Andrew Yee

data.text: I think you should consider your definition of ‚Äúcrash‚Äù. Carbon (good carbon) is much stronger than most alloy bars. Take rims for example. Aluminum alloy rims get dented and bent easily and often. Carbon rims can take far more abuse than aluminum without deforming. That said under ‚Äúsevere‚Äù impact or loads they can fail, but it‚Äôs way higher than their use permitters. In other words if you get in an accident with a car, yeah the bars might break, but‚Ä¶ Also, notice how Formula 1 cars are made out of carbon fiber? There have been some horrific crashes the past few seasons and the carbon fiber tech has been a big part of saving lives. That said, I would never consider buying some off brand Asian componentsÔøº that you don‚Äôt know what went into them (read ‚Äúdon‚Äôt buy crap‚Äù) üòâ
data.author: Mark Jake Jacobson

data.text: Short answer..yes. check out spank vibratory handlebars. Not carbon...but might be the answer you are looking for.
data.author: Dave Hunt

data.text: Short answer..yes. check out spank vibra core handlebars. Not carbon...but might be the answer you are looking for.
data.author: Dave Hunt

data.text: Yes
data.author: Brent Davis

data.text: I think the Redshift stem is the answer. If your looking for more vibration dampening, get bigger volume tires.
data.author: Dan Montgomery

data.text: , still will not change the moisture levels
data.author: Shiggy Don Person

data.text: They will break in a fall they are strong on sone aspects and brittle in others. May even make vibration worse. Just thinking as motorcycles have weights in the end of their bars to dampen vibrations
data.author: Tenchi Hoshi

data.text: Bigger volume tires with lower pressure does more dampening of vibrations than anything else. Double bar tape or thicker bar tape such as Supcaz does wonders for me.
data.author: Devinder Singh Bahia

data.text: Redshift>
data.author: Marco Crown

data.text: If you haven't already had a professional bike fit then start there.
data.author: Saj Falcon

data.text: great point. I actually got a fit on my road bike. I wanted to upgrade my shifters before my gravel fit. Figured it would be a good time to change out the bars now rather than after the fit.
data.author: Chris Hong

data.text: I would listen to fitters input on bar selection so do the fit first. Find someone with a good rep, they might have good bar options that could be added during the fit.
data.author: Saj Falcon

data.text: Will not affect the moisture level at all
data.author: Shiggy Don Person

data.text: Try playing with the elastomers in the Redshift stem, I started with the recommended colours but tweaked to be slightly softer, no adverse riding effect just a little more comfort at the bars. I also use Enve bar tape which has a great feel‚Ä¶.
data.author: Shaun Phillips

data.text: It will make the difference but the model will definitely will be important. Hi use Whiskey Bar https://whiskyparts.co/handlebars/spano-drop-handlebar#/
data.author: Sandro Cistera

data.text: I tried redshift but sent it back just make sure you‚Äôre bent at the elbow and if that fails slow down
data.author: Simon Waldron

data.text: I had carbon and switched to aluminum. Try thicker bar tape or even doubling up the bar tape. You can also try a larger front tyre for comfort. The front fork can usually take a wider tyre than the back.
data.author: Ryan Eagles

data.text: I‚Äôm no engineer but a good carbon bar can make a huge difference. My perception is that they eliminate a significant portion of the high frequency vibration. While not a fan of the flex stems I believe they are more for the low frequency big hits. I‚Äôm totally hooked on the Enve G-bars with Silca Nastro Piloti (or Nastro Cuchini) bar tape. Both super spendy, but well worth it to me. If you‚Äôre interested in some Easton EC 70 AX bars in a 44cm I‚Äôve got a brand new take off pair that are only on the bike to hang the shifters while I wait for my new G-bars. They haven‚Äôt even been torqued or wrapped yet. I‚Äôd sell them for $160 shipped in the US
data.author: Mark Jake Jacobson

data.text: I agree that I think they might help with the higher frequency vibrations. I‚Äôm assuming that fork will help a lot too!
data.author: Chris Hong

data.text: the fork is for the big stuff. I ride almost exclusively single track. That bikes a 56cm I‚Äôm building for a friend. Here‚Äôs one of my others, ‚Äúdressed to kill it‚Äù
data.author: Mark Jake Jacobson

data.text: also, when I noticed the high frequency effect was when I had my first gravel bike, and I noticed it when I went from an alloy to a carbon bar. I had a Lauf fork on it at the time, but where I noticed it most was on the street. Hard to say on the dirt, but when I was on pavement it made a noticeable difference. I deduced that there‚Äôs just too many variables off road to immediately sense the difference. I imagine if you ride them both back to back you could feel differences in the dirt. But it was just an absence of buzz on tarmac üòâ
data.author: Mark Jake Jacobson

data.text: I‚Äôm not noticing hi freq vibrations that much on fast gravel as much as I am concerned about fitment. I ride a lot more upright than I do on road, IMHO it‚Äôs tire selection and pressure that make the most consequential comfort. On road, I like Easton EC90s for the wide handhold and cyclocross, any Thomson for the continuous 31.8 diameter for my big paws.
data.author: James Chan

data.text: Depends on the bar...not all carbon is created equal. Some brands do it better than others.
data.author: Josh Kebschull

data.text: Is there one you would recommend? I'm lookin... üëÄ
data.author: Daniel Geuss

data.text: you answered your own question - not worth the cost. Just get some thicker tape if you're worried about 'high frequency vibration", harmonic distortion or whatever BS the manufacturers and GCN are peddling. I have carbon, steel and aluminium handlebars. I sure can't tell any difference.
data.author: Chris Summers
